_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2009

1.    Executive Summary

1.1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Safety and Risk Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals.  This site has developed and trained an Emergency Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies.  The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 

1.2.    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 900 E. Blanco Road in Salinas, California.  The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported and distributed from this site.

The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is 53,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Two (2) transportable (skid mounted) ammonia refrigeration systems are often located on the site, but are not interconnected to the fixed system and are not considered part of the A?processA? for this RMP.

1.3.    Release Scenarios

The worst-case release scenario considered for this process is a release of the volume of the dual High Pressure Receivers (a maximum of (32,000 lbs) .  No administrative controls and mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case scenario is 2.1 miles.

The alternative release scenario considered for this process is a release of ammonia from a ruptured liquid line caused by thermal expansion due to doubl

e blocking of the line.  The largest-volume outdoor liquid line was chosen and the entire length of this 2-inch nominal inside diameter line between blocking valves was included (394 feet).  No administrative controls or mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario even though line lockout/tagout (an administrative control) exists.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario is 0.1 mile.

1.4.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental ammonia release at Fresh Express is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original ammonia refrigeration system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications, and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.  

This includes:

A?    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction and modification

A?    Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) at least once every five years using accurate Process Safety Information

A?    Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by PHA

A?    Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel  

A?    Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous energy lockout and hot work permit programs

A?    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols

A?    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system

The detailed Prevention Program for the system is contained in a supporting document (revised and updated June, 2009), which is maintained at the siteA?s Safety Office.

1.5.    Five Year Accident History

Between June, 2003 (the previous revalidation of the site program) and the present, no ammonia releases resulted in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property d

amage, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. However, the following ammonia-related incidents occurred:

A?    In 2006 A? Auto purger malfunction resulting in a small leak that was isolated to the Engine Room. Facility was evacuated as a precaution. Equipment was repaired and additional training was  provided to the Technicians to address such malfunctions in the future. Leak estimated and <5 lbs. This event did not meet the criteria for a reportable accident.

A?    In 2008 A? Ammonia release at the roof level. The investigation determined that approximately 50 lbs of ammonia vapor was released to the air from a pin-hole leak from a failed weld (due to corrosion) in Ammonia Zone 3 Evaporator 10 piping. Entire piping was replaced. Adjacent facilities were notified and the incident was reported to Monterey County Health Department.

A?    In 2009  - On February 24 and 25, 2009 multiple reports of ammonia odors were received within specific areas of the facility. A detailed investigation eventually determined that the cause of the odors were minute cracks that had developed in the plates of a A?Plate and FrameA? chiller. These were allowing small amounts of ammonia to be dissolved in the chilled water A? eventually giving rise to the odors. This event did not meet the criteria for a reportable accident.

1.6.    Emergency Response Program

Fresh Express has developed an Emergency Planning and Response document to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to ammonia release emergencies.  The plan is maintained at the siteA?s Safety Office and reviewed annually.  The document describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, provides detailed evacuation procedures, and includes response procedures for the mitigation of ammonia releases. 

The site has an Ammonia Emergency Response Team trained to use the Incident Command System organizational framework.  This is also described in detail in th

e planning document.

1.7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the Revalidation Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) conducted on April 23, 2009 the following adjustments are planned to ensure continued safe operations:



#    Actions    PHA TableItem #    Assignee    Due Date /Status

1.        Review diffusion system design to potentially change the capacity    1    Ken    

2.        Confirm design and operation of ESO circuit    4    Michael Chase    Complete May 2009.All compressors and king valves shut off with the emergency shut off switch.  Compressors 1-3 lose control power, 4-7 shutdown on Aux 1 failure

3.        Walk system to confirm PRV/diffusion line configuration.    16    Michael Chase    Complete 5/27/09.[LPRs 3&4 have 150# bypass regulators on the diffusion lines.  1,2,3,4 Lines are 1A?.  5&6 are 2A? and need to be painted & labeled. HPR 1 line needs to be relabeled.]

4.        Add eye wash for Z1-7 and Z3-3 to provide protection for sanitation chemicals    Human Factors    Michael Chase    10/15/09. [WO 1035297, WO 1035298]

5.        Review near-miss reporting protocols with forklift drivers during tailgate meeting.    Previous Incidents and Near Misses    Vanessa Galvan    Complete. May 2009

6.        Verify Z1-7 has smoke detector     23    Michael Chase    Complete 5/27/09. [No smoke detector.] Scope defined by 6-28-09. Implementation bundled with Fire System upgrade schedule for FY 2010.

7.        Add smoke detection to Z3-3    23    Michael Chase    Scope defined by 6-28-09. Implementation bundled with Fire System upgrade schedule for FY 2010.

8.        Consider Ammonia detection in air handlers    23    Michael Chase    Reviewed 5/22/09 [Determined that it is not feasible.]

9.        Verify Fire extinguishers are accessible from Z1-7, Z3-3    23    Michael Chase    Complete 5-27-09. [WO 1035295, WO 1035296]

10.        Verify coil material of construction    24, 62    Michael Chase    Complete 5/22/09. [Hot dipped galvanized.]

11.        Verify that relays are tested semi-annually.    33    Michael Chase    6/10/09 Open.

12.        Verify that all alarms and safety-critical items are tested on a semi-annual ba

sis    33    Michael Chase    6/10/09 Open.

13.        Confirm that safety devices continue to function when one side of dual compressor shuts down    34    Michael Chase    Complete 5/22/09. [Safeties work, discharge temperature probe and oil sump temperature probe need to be wired in parallel]

14.        Consider a holding circuit reset button for king valve.    35    Michael Chase    Complete 5/31/09.     [Holding circuit is in place, labeled, and works.]

15.        Review global startup procedure to confirm scenarios are addressed    35    Michael Chase    6/10/09 Open.

16.        Develop and document procedure to rebalance Ammonia system after power failure    36    Michael Chase    6/17/09 Open.

17.        Make sure return liquid valve (Condensor 7) is locked open.    42    Michael Chase    6/15/09 Open.

18.        Develop process for determining presence of Ammonia by utilizing a A?StaticA? flow type test on a periodic basis.    Node 6A Previous Incidents    Michael Chase    6/20/09

19.        Develop process for inspecting for plate cracks in chiller system    Node 6A Previous Incidents    Michael Chase    Reviewed 5/22/09 and determined that not technically feasible until chiller dismantled.

20.        Confirm the pressure set point of the Compressor PRV    49    Michael Chase    5/27/09 Closed. [250 psig].

21.        Develop protocol to respond to eye-irritation reports in trimlines and ASL (s/d and maintain static water flow for detection    54    Vanessa Galvan    August 2009.

22.        Consider PM to check chiller water for presence of Ammonia.    54    Michael Chase    6/10/09 Open.













2004

Section One

Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Safety and Risk Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals.  This site has developed and trained an Ammonia Emergency Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies.  The site has specific

and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 900 E. Blanco Road in Salinas, California.  The facility receives lettuce, fruit and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad/fruit mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported and distributed from this site.

The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating product at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is 32,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Two (2) transportable (skid mounted) ammonia refrigeration systems are often located on the site, but are not interconnected to the fixed system and are not considered part of the "process" for this RMP.

Release Scenarios

The worst-case release scenario considered for this process is a release of the entire ammonia system charge (32,000 lbs) from the High Pressure Receivers1.  No administrative controls and mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case scenario is 2.1 miles.

The alternative release scenario considered for this process is a release of ammonia from a ruptured liquid line caused by thermal expansion due to double blocking of the line2.  The largest-volume outdoor liquid line was assumed, and the entire length of this 2-inch nominal inside diameter line between blocking valves was included (394 feet).  No administrative controls or mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario even though line lockout/tagout (an administrative control) exists.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario is 0.1 mile.

Accide

r a three-minute period(Henry Model 5601 relief valve rated at 250psig).  One employee reported to the nurse, complaining of nausea and headache.  The employee declined to see the physician and, after a brief rest, returned to work.

* On July 9, 2001 an odor was detected, and upon investigation, a defective relief valve and loose union on the pumper drum for a low-pressure receiver was found(LPR #3, pumper drum #2).  It is estimated that less than 5 pounds of ammonia were released.  Two employees reported to the nurse, complaining of irritation (eye, nose, throat) and nausea.  No follow-up treatment was required.

Emergency Response Program

Fresh Express has developed an Emergency Planning and Response document to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to ammonia release emergencies.  The plan (current document Rev 1, dated June 2004) is maintained at the site's Safety and Risk Management Office.  The document describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, provides detailed evacuation procedures, and includes response procedures for the mitigation of ammonia releases. 

The site has an Ammonia Emergency Response Team trained to use the Incident Command System organizational framework.  This is also described in detail in the planning document.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the studies conducted during preparation of this RMP, the following adjustments are planned to ensure continued safe operations:
